thread.title: I-10 on-, off-ramps closed at 16th Street in Phoenix for protest
thread.title_full: I-10 on-, off-ramps closed at 16th Street in Phoenix for protest

author: Johana Restrepo and Laura Gómez , The Republic | azcentral.com
title: I-10 on-, off-ramps closed at 16th Street in Phoenix for protest
text:
Protesters gather on 16th Street over Interstate 10 to hold signs to the traffic below in Phoenix, Ariz. on Feb. 17, 2017. (Photo: Courtney Pedroza/The Republic) 
728 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 15 COMMENT EMAIL MORE About 50 people protesting President Donald Trump's immigration policies stood along an Interstate 10 overpass in Phoenix Friday afternoon, forcing state and local police agencies to shut down the 16th Street freeway ramps during rush hour.
UPDATE: The I-10 eastbound and westbound exit ramps at 16th Street are open. #phxtraffic https://t.co/8uIn6gSGMs 
— Arizona DOT (@ArizonaDOT) February 18, 2017 The crowd held signs directed toward the freeway traffic passing beneath while shouting slogans denouncing the president. Many cars honked as they passed under 16th Street bridge.
Multiple Phoenix police and Arizona Department of Public Safety vehicles and personnel were on the freeway ramps at 16th Street just before 4 p.m., which were closed off to traffic. Arizona Department of Transportation tweeted that it reopened at 7:14 p.m. on Friday.
Sgt. Mercedes Fortune, a Phoenix police spokeswoman, said authorities were on hand to make sure that both protesters and motorists were safe.
"We're protesting against Trump and his administration. I don't condone what he's done so far,'' said Hannah Trinh, one of the protesters. "I believe we all have a say and have the right to go against him.''
Autumn Kidd, another protester, added: "I want to show solidarity with people who are being marginalized by his administration.''
Gabriel Fuentes stands with protesters on 16th Street over Interstate 10 to hold signs to the traffic below in Phoenix, Ariz. on Feb. 17, 2017.   (Photo: Courtney Pedroza/The Republic) 
Cruz Hernandez, 63, is a resident of El Mirage who showed up Friday afternoon in support of "justice for immigrants,'' he said.
"If the animal kingdom can live without borders, why can't humans?" he said standing on the I-10 overpass on 16th Street.
The protesters held signs facing the westbound traffic on I-10 during a peak commute time.
Some of the cars below honked their horns and gave them a thumbs-up, while others shouted expletives at the crowd while traveling on the highway.
Several protesters said they found out about the demonstration via Facebook.
Phoenix police reminded the crowd to keep their signs on the inside of the freeway overpass fence and to avoid climbing on the fence.
Return to azcentral.com for more details.
